content.description: Start right hand on a chest level edge, with a thumb on the side, and left hand on a slightly lower side pull. Left foot goes below the Right hand. Work your way up and right to a high hidden dish to top out on.
content.protection: Two pads at the bottom and a spotter is comfortable.
content.location: Untie the rope from the tree and move it to the side. There is a rock sticking out of the ground just to the left of this slab. Although mostly out of the way there is potential to fall and hit it. Good idea to have a spotter.

content.description: Climb the line using compression between the two sides. The crux is the high left heel and figuring out where to go with left hand. Top out is potentially sketchy as well.
content.location: Back/lowest part of the boulder, right side. There is a crack along the arete with a green line at hip height, and that is your right hand. Your left hand starts on crimp just to the left of the crack to your left. After that use the crack.

content.description:
THERE IS A BIT OF ROCK AT THE BOTTOM OF THE RIGHT CRACK/GAP THAT WIGGLES. AVOID STEPPING ON IT. 

 Interesting line that involves side pulls, pinches and jugs.
content.location: Start at the back of the boulder, at its lowest point. Start on a knee high bit of rock that is smooth. There is a crack that goes up the side of it all the way to the top of the boulder. (Left most crack on the wall). Match hands in the crack where the rock comes back out towards you (head height) , then work your way out right and up the gap to your right. Climb up that line using anything you can. The starting crack can be used as a good left hand side pull.

content.description: Traverse across the juggy bit shoulder height at overhanging side of boulder. (Right side to left side). Then, climb up crack using whatever feet you can find. There is a left hand crimp and sidepull that are used to help here. Top out the climb.
content.protection: At least two pads and a spotter. Leave one pad covering the corner of the rock below the crack top out. Drag the other one below your climber.
content.location: Just to the right of the overhanging face. There is a plant growing out of a juggy section of rock about shoulder height. Place both hands just left to the plant and work your way left.

content.description: Awesome juggy traverse with minimal feet. There are a few options to toe jam, toe hook or heel. There aren't really any low feet, and the jugs are quite far back. Ideally you can cover your arms with a long sleeve shirt or prepare to scrape your arm up a little bit on the traverse. Although juggy, the lack of low feet options and the holds being far back make it quite pumpy.
content.protection: Pad or two. Need spotter. First pad dragged underneath you as you do overhang, and other pad or two set up near top out.
content.location: Start underneath the overhang, all the way to the left. Pull onto the rock just above a turkey sized rock in the ground and start moving right. Once you get to the end of the traverse, pull yourself up and top out straight above. There is a small plant growing out of a juggy crack at the end up the traverse. As soon as you see that, you're done traversing, and instead are moving upward.

content.description: Fun pinch/sidepull problem. Can be done dynamically. There aren't a whole lot of feet in the middle of the climb. Work your way up the crack to where it rounds off into a jug. Find whatever feet you can and top out.
content.location: At the rightmost corner of the bottom of the rock, there is a crack and a nice foot spot just below. Start with hands matched on the side pull just above the green spray paint line. Right foot low on obvious spot and left pressed into the side of the wall.

content.description: Start on gastoned right hand rail below big dish. Left hand goes to a lower rail. Move up and into the dish, and top out above it. There is a nice edge to reach for at the top, just hidden. Scope it out or trust yourself.
content.location: Right-most side of the slab wall. There is an obvious bowl, dish half way up the boulder. Start just below that.

content.description: Tall, standalone boulder on the top of the hill. There will be a large overhang sticking out as you walk up to it, and a rope on the slab side.
